qas.question: Lenin acknowledged the independence of which countries?

answers.text: Finland, Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania and Poland.

qas.question: What agreement gave Germany many regions of Russia in the first world war?
When did the russian civil war take place?

plausible_answers.text: Finland, Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania and Poland

qas.question: Lenin never acknowledged the independence of which countries?

plausible_answers.text: Finland, Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania and Poland

qas.question: Lenin acknowledged the dependence of which countries?
What agreement gave Germany many regions of Russia in the second world war?
What agreement gave Germany no of Russia in the first world war?
When did the russian civil war not take place?

context: The outcome of the First World War was disastrous for both the German Reich and the Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic. During the war, the Bolsheviks struggled for survival, and Vladimir Lenin recognised the independence of <a0_0><b3_0><b4_0>Finland, Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania and Poland<b4_0/><b3_0/>.<a0_0/> Moreover, facing a German military advance, Lenin and Trotsky were forced to enter into the <a1_0><b5_0><b6_0>Treaty of Brest-Litovsk<b6_0/><b5_0/><a1_0/>, which ceded massive western Russian territories to the German Empire. After Germany's collapse, a multinational Allied-led army intervened in the Russian Civil War (<a2_0><b7_0>1917–22<b7_0/><a2_0/>).
